moves.1. Nc3 Nc6 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Ne5 Ne4 4. Nxc6: We keep the symmetry, and free our bishops first...
moves.9. c4 dxc4 10. Bxc4: ...then we exchange pawns for the first time...
moves.10... c5 11. dxc5 Bxc5: ...and again, making the board symmetric again.
moves.13. a3 a6: And again with our pawns on the far side...
moves.14. Bxa6 Rxa6: ...but the symmetry is now destroyed, as I accept the gift of a bishop, giving me the edge.
moves.15. h4 Bd7: I bring my other bishop up...
moves.17. Kf3 Rd8: Now I unleash my other rook.
moves.18. b4 Bxb4: I decide it's worth removing the pawn...
moves.19. Bb2: ...but my opponent doesn't take the bait, keeping his rook concealed.
moves.19... Bc6+: So instead, I attack the king again...
moves.20. Kg3 Bd2: ...and put the other bishop deep into enemy territory.
moves.21... Bxe3: ...so remove another pawn, exposing my rook to my opponent's, although the king is on a neighbouring square. Would my rook be classed as being en prise?
moves.22. Rde1: My opponent decides to line up my bishop instead...
moves.23. Kg4: The king has now exposed a pawn...
moves.25. Kg5 Kf7 26. Bh6: The bishop is forced to retreat...
moves.26... Ra4: ...so my rook lines up a checkmate.
moves.27. Kh5: The king makes his only possible move...
moves.27... Bf3+: ...allowing one of my bishops to attack him...
moves.28. Kg5: ...forcing him to make his only possible move...

gameName: No queens or knights... how will you do? II
